Other details you may want to know
My second passion, right after development, is science. Especially stars' science ( astrophysics and cosmology) and life sciences (biology).
If you mix these two passions, you get bio-informatics. I never tried it but it looks really appealing.
Besides that, I really like swimming (but I don't practice it very much) and I write a few blog posts. I play the guitar and a little bit of piano when I feel like it.

The information on this web or PDF version of my resume are updated regularly but the PDF version is not exactly the same. For evident reasons, the PDF resume is shorter and less detailed than the web version, some information might not appear there.

Hi, my name is Nathanaël Cherrier, I am a Javascript/iOS developer, teacher, blogger, and an aspiring technical expert living in Lyon. Coding has been my passion for 13 years and I am always eager to learn more about new technologies and to better myself. I have a lead developer position in a startup where I code, of course, but also teach other about good practices and Javascript/Angular/Swift.

I have an instagram account where I share my life as a developer. My audience is international and I'll be glad to use it to help you reach out more people with your company! I am willing to promote your products/brands if I like them and they suit my account guidelines.
For detailed pricing, please contact me.

trans-unit.note: Show how many tech post are written on the blog
Show how many OSS project are maintained

trans-unit.source: As a passionate developer, I pour my heart into giving back to open source. I learned most of what I know thanks to the open internet, so it feels normal for me to teach and help on the internet. I use open source projects every single day so contributing to open source projects feels like a good way to show how grateful I am for everyone maintaining projects.
Currently, I write 1 to 2 posts a week in average, I contribute to several open source projects and I'm the maintainer of of them.
If you want to know how to support my projects, please click down below.
Oups! It seems like we didn't find what you want.
An unknown error occured. Sorry for trouble.

Did you find something helpful on the blog and are feeling a little grateful today?
I have been coding for 15+ years and love using this blog to show what I learned during this continuous process of being a developper! I work full-time so this blog and my open source projects are mainly updated on my free time which is, as a dad and husband, very precious.
I love to share with you what I learn everyday for free and I am trying my best to keep it this way, though costs are getting higher for me and I wouldn't say no to a little help from you.
Your support would mean I could take days off or make more room in my schedule to offer you better quality content more often.
As I don't want my website to turn into an ugly mess, you can see there no ads at all here!
trans-unit.note: A text that explain how many work is done for free

trans-unit.source: It's often hard for people to figure out what is part of my daily workload. So, here what I do:
I share my knowledge on my blog in the form of tech posts, tech event reports, product reviews and tutorials.
I document my life on Instagram. You'll find motivational posts, "dev life" posts, and friendly advice for newbies.
I maintain several open source projects on Github.
I am very grateful for the community I have build with this platform and all the emails you guys send me telling me how my posts or projects helped in some ways.
Here are a few ways you can support the blog.

trans-unit.note: The title of the Patreon section on the support page

trans-unit.source: Patreon is an opportunity for you to support me and get a little something in exchange. You can see the rewards available directly on my Patreon page. It can last for as long as you desire for a minimum of 1$/month.
Donate with Patreon and get rewards
trans-unit.note: The title of the Patreon action button
The alternative text of the Patreon action button
The title of the one-shot payment section

trans-unit.source: If you don't want to be committed to a monthly subscription, you can also donate by Paypal or directly with your credit card.
trans-unit.note: The description paragraph for one-shot payments

trans-unit.source: Donate with Paypal or by credit card
trans-unit.note: The title of the Paypal action button
The alternative text of the Paypal action button
The title of the crypto section

trans-unit.source: If you feel a little nerdy (I am SO nerdy), you can also contribute to the blog by using your crypto-currencies. The website supports Litecoin, Bitcoin, Ethereum and Ripple.

You can also send some Basic Atention Token (BAT) using the Brave browser. It is easier and secure. You just have to install the browser and start using it. When you are on my website you can choose to send a tip to me by clicking on the icon of BAT in the address bar. Here is a video to better show you how to do so.
trans-unit.note: Crypto payments can be done using Brave browser

trans-unit.source: Can't support my blog with money? Please do share on social media the posts you appreciate! It helps tremendously.
trans-unit.note: Even if people don't have money they can support us
